23.07.text: the evolutionary ascent of our species

27.70.text: from the last common ancestor with the chimpanzee,

30.77.text: something extraordinary happened to us less than 100.000 years ago,

34.50.text: which by the way, is long after we've become anatomically modern.

38.89.text: It was a kind of emergence into consciousness

42.63.text: less than 100.000 years ago, really less than 40.000 years ago,

46.83.text: when we became fully symbolic creatures.

50.53.text: And this great change has been defined as

53.70.text: the single most important step forward in the evolution of human behavior,

57.14.text: is intimately associated with the emergence of the great and transcendant

61.18.text: rock and cave art all around the world.

65.85.text: And over the last 30 years researchers led by prof. David Louis Williams,

70.66.text: at the University of Witwatersrand in South Africa, and many others,

74.74.text: have suggested an intriguing and radical possibility

78.62.text: which is that this emergence into consciousness was triggered by

82.85.text: our ancestors encounters with visionary plants

89.96.text: If you analyze the cave art - there's no time to go into the details here, but there are

93.91.text: so many details that make it clear that this was an art of altered states of consciousness,

100.22.text: and that plants like the Amanita muscaria mushroom, or Psilocybin mushrooms,

107.98.text: appear to have been directly connected with this sudden and radical change.

114.58.text: So to investigate this possibility when I got interested in this mistery,

118.94.text: I went down to the Amazon, where there are still surviving shamanistic cultures today,

125.41.text: and where they drink the powerful visionary brew Ayahuasca,

129.74.text: of which the active ingredient is Dimethyltryptamine, DMT,

133.65.text: which is actually closelly related at the molecular level to Psilocybin.

138.44.text: Now normally DMT cannot be activated orally when we encountered it in the West,

147.53.text: There's an enzyme in our stomachs called monoaminoxidaze

151.48.text: which switches off DMT on contact.

156.00.text: But in the Amazon they've got round this problem.

158.91.text: And they say it was the spirits that taught them how to do it.

162.57.text: The DMT in the Ayahuasca brew is contained in these leaves

165.75.text: from a plant that they call Chacruna in the Amazon.

169.15.text: And there they mix it together with this vine,

172.55.text: and out of the 150.000 different species of plants and trees in the Amazon

176.46.text: this is the one that contains a monoaminoxidaze inhibitor,

180.74.text: which switches off that enzyme in our stomachs

184.74.text: and allows the DMT in the leaves when the two are maried together and cooked in water

188.91.text: to be absorbed orally, and takes us on a 4 hour journey

197.26.text: Now it's no joke to drink Ayahuasca.

201.72.text: The Ayahuasca brew has a foul taste.

206.87.text: Really, really hideous and a dreadful, dreadful smell.

210.69.text: And after you've drunk your cup, you'll find within 45 minutes or so

214.63.text: that your sweating, that you're feeling nauseous.

217.62.text: Pretty soon you may well be vomiting, you may well having diarrhea.

220.42.text: So, nobody is doing this for recreation.

225.25.text: And I'd like to add that I don't think any of the psychedelics should be used for recreation.

230.50.text: They have much more serious and important mission with humanity.

236.45.text: So we're not doing this for fun. But what draws people to Ayahuasca again and again

240.58.text: to brace themselves for this experience - and you do have to brace yourself -

243.87.text: is its extraordinary effects at the level of consciousness.

247.26.text: And one of those effects has to do with creativity.

250.42.text: And we can see the creative cosmogenic impulse of Ayahuasca in the paintings

254.78.text: of Ayahuasca Shamans from Peru, like the paintings of Pablo Amaringo here -

259.34.text: those richly saturated colors, the amazing visions that they reproduce -

264.35.text: and this creative impulse has also spread to western artists.

269.87.text: Many western artists now have been deeply influenced by Ayahuasca

273.75.text: and are also painting their visions.

276.46.text: And as these paintings show, another universal experience of Ayahuasca

280.78.text: is the encounter with seemingly intelligent entities which communicate with us telepathically,

287.26.text: and I am making no claim one way or another as to the reality status of these entities we encounter.

291.90.text: Simply that phenomenologically, in the Ayahuasca experience they are encountered

296.50.text: by people all over the world, and most frequently of all,

299.35.text: the spirit of Ayahuasca herself - Mother Ayahuasca - who is a healer

306.92.text: and although she is kind of the mother goddess of the planet

310.58.text: she seems to take a direct personal interest in us as individuals,

315.02.text: to heal our ills, to want us to be the best that we can possibly be,

319.70.text: to correct errors and mistakes in our behavior that may be leading us down the wrong path.

325.47.text: And this is perhaps why, and it's an untold story, really -

330.38.text: Ayahuasca has been fantastically successful in getting people off harmful addictions to hard drugs

337.31.text: such as heroine and cocaine. Jacques Mabit at the Takiwasi clinic in Peru,

343.10.text: brings heroine and cocaine addicts out there for a month,

346.09.text: gives them 12 Ayahuasca sessions and they have encounters with Mother Ayahuasca

350.04.text: during those sessions that lead them not to wish to take heroine and cocaine any more,

355.22.text: and more than half leave completely free of their addiction,

358.06.text: never return to it and don't even have withdrawal symptoms.

361.34.text: The same incredible healing work has been done in Canada by doctor Gabor Mate

365.59.text: until the Canadian Government interviened and stopped his healing practice

369.82.text: on the grounds that Ayahuasca itself was an illegal drug.

375.12.text: Now I have some personal experience of this. I have not been addicted to heroine or cocaine,

380.58.text: but I had a 24 years non-stop cannabis habit.

384.15.text: This started off smoking the herb and laterally vaporizing it,

390.65.text: but the basic truth is that for 24 years I was pretty much permanently stoned.

396.54.text: And I enjoyed it, being stoned and I felt that it helped me with my work as a writter and

404.95.text: perhaps at some point it did, but when I first encountered Ayahuasca

408.70.text: I had already been smoking cannabis for 16 years and almost immediatelly

412.30.text: Ayahuasca started giving me messages that this was no longer serving me,

417.57.text: that it was leading me to behave in negative and unhelpful ways towards others,

422.38.text: and of course I ignored those messages for years and years

425.66.text: and went back to being stoned 16 hours a day.

429.43.text: But that negative behavior that Ayahuasca was pointing out did actually get worse and worse.

435.83.text: I don't want to put down cannabis and I believe it's the sovereign right of every adult

439.40.text: to choose to smoke cannabis if they wish to do so,

441.98.text: but I think I was overusing it, I think I was abusing it, not using it responsibly.

446.47.text: And I became more and more paranoid, jealous, possessive, suspicious,

451.58.text: I was subject to irrational rages, I often made the life of my beloved partner, Santha,

456.50.text: a misery, and when I went down for my regular encounter with Ayahuasca,

461.58.text: in October 2011, I was given the most unbelievable kicking by Mother Ayahuasca.

468.52.text: And I was put through an ordeal. It was a kind of life review

474.66.text: and it's not an accident that Ayahuasca is the vine of the dead.

479.60.text: I was shown my death, and I was shown that if I came to death

484.56.text: and what awaits us after death without having corrected the mistakes that I was making

489.42.text: in my life, that it would be a very bad thing for me, and actually

494.06.text: Mother Ayahuasca literally took me to hell.

497.70.text: And that hell was a little like this "Hell" painted by Hieronymus Bosch.

502.95.text: A truly horrible place. And a little like the place that

506.82.text: the ancient Egyptians called the Judgement Hall of Osiris,

510.06.text: where our souls are weighed in the scale in the presence of the Gods

513.89.text: against the feather of truth, of justice, of cosmic harmony.

518.22.text: And I was shown that the path I was walking,

521.18.text: my abuse of Cannabis and the behavior associated with it

525.74.text: was going to lead me to be found "wanting" in the judgement

529.77.text: and that I might face annihilation in the world beyond death,

534.03.text: so perhaps not surprising, but when I came back to England,

538.14.text: later in October 2011, I gave up Cannabis

541.83.text: and I've never smoked it again since then.

545.10.text: And actually and again I'm speaking only personally with no comment on

548.47.text: other uses of Cannabis. It's as though a monkey has been lifted off my back.

553.06.text: I'm liberated in incredible ways. Far from my creativity being inhibited,

557.62.text: I find myself writing much more productively, much more creatively,

561.38.text: much more focused and much more efficiently as well,

566.30.text: and I began to be able to address those negative aspects of my behavior

569.54.text: which Cannabis had revealed and hopefully to make myself slowly -

572.82.text: it's a long progress - into a more nurturing, more loving, more positive person

577.45.text: and this whole transformation - it really has been a personal transformation for me -

582.62.text: was made possible by this encounter with Death that Mother Ayahuasca gave me.

587.46.text: And you know, that leads me to ask what is Death?

590.75.text: Our materialist science reduces everything to matter,

594.13.text: and materialist science in the West says we are just meat, we are just our bodies,

597.75.text: so when the brain is dead that's the end of consciousness,

600.90.text: there is no life after death, there is no soul,

602.82.text: we just rot and are gone.

606.03.text: But actually many honest scientists should admit

609.98.text: that consciousness is the greatest mystery of science

613.04.text: and that we don't know exactly how it works.

615.54.text: The brain is involved in it in some way,

617.34.text: but we're not sure how. Could be that the brain generates consciousness

621.52.text: the way a generator makes electricity, if you hold to that paradigm,

624.98.text: then of course you can't believe in life after death.

627.02.text: When the generator is broken consciousness is gone,

629.18.text: but it's equally possible that the relationship -

630.90.text: and nothing in neuro-science rules it out -

632.93.text: that the relationship is more like a relationship of the TV signal to the TV set.

636.96.text: And in that case, when the TV set is broken, of course the TV signal continues.

641.79.text: And this is the paradigm of all spiritual traditions,

645.69.text: that we are immortal souls, temporarily incarnated in these physical forms,

650.18.text: to learn and to grow and to develop.

653.62.text: And really if we want to know about this mystery

656.18.text: the last people we should ask are materialist - reductionist scientists.

659.18.text: They have nothing to say on the matter at all.

661.26.text: Let's go rather to the ancient Egyptians who put their best minds to work

664.82.text: for 3000 years on the problem of death,

666.74.text: and on the problem of how we should live our lives to prepare

670.46.text: for what we will confront after death.

672.69.text: And the ancient Egyptians expressed their ideas in transcendent art

678.02.text: which still touches us emotionally today

680.53.text: and they came to certain very specific conclusions,

683.15.text: that the soul does survive death, and that we will be held accountable for

686.99.text: every thought, every action, every deed that we have lived through in our lives,

692.20.text: so we better take this precious opportunity - to be born in a human body -

695.86.text: seriously and make the most of it.

698.51.text: And in these inquiries into the mystery of death

701.14.text: the ancient Egyptians weren't just exercising their imagination.

704.11.text: They highly valued dream states, and it's now known that they used visionary plants -

709.95.text: like the hallucinogenic blue Water lily,

713.62.text: and it's interesting that the ancient Egyptian tree of life

716.82.text: has recently been identified as the Acacia nilotica,

720.38.text: which contains high quantities of DMT - Dimethyltryptamine

725.42.text: the same active ingredient that we find in Ayahuasca.

729.02.text: Now it's difficult to imagine a society more different from

732.58.text: the society of ancient Egypt than our society today.

735.22.text: We hate visionary states in this society.

737.46.text: In our society, if we want to insult somebody, we call them a dreamer.

741.74.text: In ancient societies that was praise.

743.71.text: And we have erected huge apparatuses of armed burocracies

748.14.text: who will invade our privacy, who will break down our doors,

750.90.text: who will arrest us, who will send us to prison, sometimes for years,

754.26.text: for possessing even small quantities of Psilocybin or substances like DMT,

759.22.text: whether in its smokable form or in the Ayahuasca brew

762.92.text: and yet ironically DMT is - we now know - a natural brain hormone.

766.66.text: We all have it in our bodies and it's just that its function

769.79.text: remains unknown for lack of research.

772.35.text: And it's not as though our society is opposed in principle to altered states of consciousness.

776.58.text: I mean billions are being made by the unholy alliance of psychiatrists and big pharma

784.11.text: in over prescribing drugs to control so called syndromes like depression,

789.86.text: or attention deficit disorder in teenagers.

793.70.text: And we have a love affair in our society with alcohol.

798.37.text: We glorify this most boring of drugs at the spite that there are terrible consequences

806.58.text: And of course we love our stimulants: our tea, our coffee, our energy drinks, our sugar,

810.71.text: and huge industries are built around these substances,

815.77.text: which are valued because of the way they alter consciousness.

818.86.text: But what all these approved altered states of consciousness have in common

822.79.text: is that none of them contradict or conflict with the basic state of consciousness valued by our society,

827.77.text: which I would call "the alert problem solving state of consciousness",

830.45.text: which is good for the more mundane aspects of science.

833.82.text: It's good for the prosecution of warfare, it's good for commerce, it's good for politics,

837.87.text: but I think everybody realizes that the promise of a society over monopolistically based

843.82.text: upon of this state of consciousness has proved hollow.

846.99.text: And that this model is no longer working.

850.88.text: That it's broken in every possible sense that a model can be broken.

854.37.text: And urgently we need to find something to replace it:

858.34.text: the vast problems of global pollution that have resulted from the single minded pursuit of profit,

865.06.text: the horrors of a nuclear proliferation,

872.43.text: that millions every night go to bed starving.

874.98.text: And we can't even solve this problem

877.28.text: despite our alert problem solving state of consciousness.

880.14.text: And look what's happening in the Amazon - the lungs of our planet, this precious home of biodiversity -

885.90.text: the old growth rainforest being cut down and replaced with soya bean farms

891.25.text: so we can feed cattles so that we can all eat hamburgers.

894.74.text: Only a truly insane global state of consciousness could allow such an abomination to occur.

901.93.text: And I did a back of an envelope calculation during the Irak war.

906.62.text: It seems to me that 6 months expenditure on the Irak war

910.18.text: would have solved the problem of the Amazon forever.

913.02.text: Would be sufficient to compensate the peoples of the Amazon so that

916.27.text: no single tree ever needed to be cut down again,

919.52.text: to garden and look after that amazing resource.

922.01.text: But we can't make that decision as a global community.

925.96.text: We can spend countless billions on warfare,

928.72.text: on hatred, on fear, on suspicion, on division,

931.51.text: but we can't get together the collective effort to save the lungs of our planet.

938.82.text: Shamans from the Amazon are now mounting a kind of reverse missionary activity.

943.66.text: When I've asked Shamans about the sickness of the West they say it's quite simple:

947.94.text: "You guys have severed your connection with spirit.

951.79.text: Unless you reconnect with spirit and do so soon, you're going to bring the whole house of cards

958.22.text: down around your heads and ours."

960.70.text: And rightly or wrongly they believe that Ayahuasca is the remedy for that sickness.

965.54.text: And many now are being called to the Amazon to drink Ayahuasca

968.98.text: and Ayahuasca Shamans are traveling throughout the West,

971.46.text: offering the brew, often under the radar, often at personal risk

977.62.text: And it's true that the message of Ayahuasca, the universal message,

980.33.text: is about the sacred, magical, enchanted, infinitely precious, nature of life on Earth,

986.28.text: and the interdependence of material and spiritual realms.

989.16.text: And it's impossible to work with Ayahuasca for long,

991.34.text: without being deeply and profoundly affected by this message.

995.10.text: And lets not forget that Ayahuasca is not alone.

998.22.text: That it's part of an ancient worldwide system of the targeted, careful, responsible

1005.74.text: It's recently been shown by scholars that the Kykeon used in the Eleusinian mysteries

1011.14.text: in ancient Greece was almost certainly a psychedelic brew

1014.58.text: that the Soma of the Vedas may well of been a brew based upon the Amanita muscaria mushroom.

1020.06.text: We have the DMT in the ancient Egyptian tree of life,

1024.77.text: we have the whole global cultures of surviving shamanism.

1028.74.text: And what it's all about is a state of consciousness

1030.99.text: that's designed to help us find balanced harmony.

1033.30.text: The ancient Egyptians would have called it Maât with the Universe,

1036.90.text: and to remain mindful that what we're here to undertake on Earth,

1040.19.text: while immersed in matter, is fundamentally a spiritual journey

1043.74.text: aimed at the growth and perfection of the soul,

1046.16.text: a journey that may go back to the very origins of what made us human in the first place.

1050.86.text: And I stand here invoking the hard one right of freedom of speech

1055.85.text: to call for and demand another right to be recognized,

1060.16.text: and that is the right of adult sovereignty over consciousness.

1062.94.text: There's a war on consciousness in our society

1066.34.text: and if we, as adults, are not allowed to make sovereign decisions

1069.27.text: about what to experience with our own consciousness while doing no harm to others,

1073.38.text: including the decision to use responsibly ancient and sacred visionary plants,

1078.52.text: then we cannot claim to be free in any way.

1080.94.text: And it's useless for our society to go around the world imposing our form of democracy on others

1085.70.text: while we nourish this rot at the heart of society

1088.74.text: and we do not allow individual freedom over the consciousness.

1092.06.text: It may even be that we are denying ourselves the next vital step in our own evolution

1097.87.text: by allowing the state of affairs to continue,

1100.89.text: and who knows, perhaps our immortal destiny as well.
